publicwhip.spmotion: *S1M-216 Michael Russell: Human Rights in China and Tibet—That the Parliament notes that a wide range of individuals wished to bear witness to the continuing international concern regarding the Chinese treatment of Tibet and her people and about many aspects of democratic human rights in China; regrets the heavy handed attitude shown to peaceful and legitimate protests during the recent presidential visit, and agrees that, while a visit by the Chinese President to Scotland would be welcome, those who disagree with his government should have the right to show that disagreement fully protected during any such visit.
S1M-216 Human Rights in China and Tibet (lodged on 22 October 1999) Mr Lloyd Quinan*, Alex Neil*, Ms Margo MacDonald*
S1M-216 Human Rights in China and Tibet (lodged on 22 October 1999) Fiona Hyslop*, Mr Kenneth Gibson*
S1M-216 Human Rights in China and Tibet (lodged on 22 October 1999) Linda Fabiani*, Roseanna Cunningham*, Alasdair Morgan*, Michael Matheson*

S1M-216 Michael Russell: Human Rights in China and Tibet—That the Parliament notes that a wide range of individuals wished to bear witness to the continuing international concern regarding the Chinese treatment of Tibet and her people and about many aspects of democratic human rights in China; regrets the heavy handed attitude shown to peaceful and legitimate protests during the recent presidential visit, and agrees that, while a visit by the Chinese President to Scotland would be welcome, those who disagree with his government should have the right to show that disagreement fully protected during any such visit. Supported by: Mr Lloyd Quinan, Alex Neil, Ms Margo MacDonald, Fiona Hyslop, Mr Kenneth Gibson, Linda Fabiani, Roseanna Cunningham, Alasdair Morgan, Michael Matheson, Mr Adam Ingram*
S1M-216 Human Rights in China and Tibet (lodged on 22 October 1999) Mr Duncan Hamilton*

S1M-216 Michael Russell: Human Rights in China and Tibet—That the Parliament notes that a wide range of individuals wished to bear witness to the continuing international concern regarding the Chinese treatment of Tibet and her people and about many aspects of democratic human rights in China; regrets the heavy handed attitude shown to peaceful and legitimate protests during the recent presidential visit, and agrees that, while a visit by the Chinese President to Scotland would be welcome, those who disagree with his government should have the right to show that disagreement fully protected during any such visit. Supported by: Mr Lloyd Quinan, Alex Neil, Ms Margo MacDonald, Fiona Hyslop, Mr Kenneth Gibson, Linda Fabiani, Roseanna Cunningham, Alasdair Morgan, Michael Matheson, Mr Adam Ingram, Mr Duncan Hamilton
S1M-216 Human Rights in China and Tibet (lodged on 22 October 1999) Andrew Wilson*

S1M-216 Michael Russell: Human Rights in China and Tibet-That the Parliament notes that a wide range of individuals wished to bear witness to the continuing international concern regarding the Chinese treatment of Tibet and her people and about many aspects of democratic human rights in China; regrets the heavy handed attitude shown to peaceful and legitimate protests during the recent presidential visit, and agrees that, while a visit by the Chinese President to Scotland would be welcome, those who disagree with his government should have the right to show that disagreement fully protected during any such visit. Supported by: Mr Lloyd Quinan, Alex Neil, Ms Margo MacDonald, Fiona Hyslop, Mr Kenneth Gibson, Linda Fabiani, Roseanna Cunningham, Alasdair Morgan, Michael Matheson, Mr Adam Ingram, Mr Duncan Hamilton, Andrew Wilson

S1M-216 Michael Russell: Human Rights in China and Tibet—That the Parliament notes that a wide range of individuals wished to bear witness to the continuing international concern regarding the Chinese treatment of Tibet and her people and about many aspects of democratic human rights in China; regrets the heavy handed attitude shown to peaceful and legitimate protests during the recent presidential visit, and agrees that, while a visit by the Chinese President to Scotland would be welcome, those who disagree with his government should have the right to show that disagreement fully protected during any such visit. Supported by: Mr Lloyd Quinan, Alex Neil, Ms Margo MacDonald, Fiona Hyslop, Mr Kenneth Gibson, Linda Fabiani, Roseanna Cunningham, Alasdair Morgan, Michael Matheson, Mr Adam Ingram, Mr Duncan Hamilton, Andrew Wilson, Tricia Marwick*
S1M-216 Human Rights in China and Tibet (lodged on 22 October 1999) Mr Kenny MacAskill*

S1M-216 Michael Russell: Human Rights in China and Tibet—That the Parliament notes that a wide range of individuals wished to bear witness to the continuing international concern regarding the Chinese treatment of Tibet and her people and about many aspects of democratic human rights in China; regrets the heavy handed attitude shown to peaceful and legitimate protests during the recent presidential visit, and agrees that, while a visit by the Chinese President to Scotland would be welcome, those who disagree with his government should have the right to show that disagreement fully protected during any such visit. Supported by: Mr Lloyd Quinan, Alex Neil, Ms Margo MacDonald, Fiona Hyslop, Mr Kenneth Gibson, Linda Fabiani, Roseanna Cunningham, Alasdair Morgan, Michael Matheson, Mr Adam Ingram, Mr Duncan Hamilton, Andrew Wilson, Tricia Marwick, Mr Kenny MacAskill
